explanation:
Correct calculation: \(46^\circ + 115^\circ + k = 180^\circ\)  
\(161^\circ + k = 180^\circ\)  
\(k = 19^\circ\)

Student's likely error: \(115^\circ + k = 180^\circ\)  
\(k = 65^\circ\)

The student treated only two angles (115° and k) as forming the straight line, ignoring the third angle (46°). This stems from incorrectly assuming that any pair of adjacent angles on a line must sum to 180°, rather than recognizing that all angles forming the straight line must collectively total 180°. 

This directly aligns with the misconception that "any adjacent angles sum to 180°," as the student subtracted only one adjacent angle (115°) from 180° instead of summing all three. It differs from "angles on a straight line add to 100°" because the student used 180° in their (flawed) calculation. The error is not about vertical angles or misidentifying the angle being asked.
